Strengthening Capacity of the ASEAN Secretariat in

I.   INTRODUCTION   
1.  After the 1997/98 Asian financial crisis, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations 
(ASEAN) realized it needed to heighten regional cooperation and integration (RCI) among its 
members. Foremost among RCI initiatives since then are the ASEAN Surveillance Process 
(ASP), ASEAN+3 Economic Review and Policy Dialogue (ERPD), the Chiang Mai Initiative 
(CMI), and the ASEAN+3 Asian Bond Markets Initiative (ABMI). Subsequently, with the setback 
of the multilateral trading system and, most recently, the suspension of Doha Development 
Round of the World Trade Organization (WTO), ASEAN members have worked even more 
closely together to take advantage of opportunities in regional cooperation.   
2.  At the Ninth ASEAN Summit held in Bali, Indonesia, in October 2003, ASEAN leaders 
declared  that  an  ASEAN  Economic  Community  (AEC)  would  be  the  end  goal  of  ASEAN 
economic integration by 2020; the time was later accelerated to 2015 at the ASEAN Summit in 
January  2007  in  Cebu,  Philippines.  The  AEC  aims  to  transform  ASEAN  into  a  stable, 
prosperous, and highly competitive region with equitable economic development, and reduced 
poverty and socioeconomic disparities. To support this process, the ASEAN Secretariat (ASEC) 
is  expected  to  (i)  provide  in-depth  policy  inputs  for  ASEAN  policy  dialogues on  economic 
integration in regional forums such as the ASEAN Economic Ministers (AEM) and the ASEAN 
Finance Ministers (AFM) processes; and (ii) monitor and enforce AEC implementation. 
3.  Due to the increased burden arising from the quickened pace of regional cooperation 
and deepening efforts in regional integration, ASEC—whose resources are overstretched—
needs  to  increase  its  capacity  to  adequately  perform  its  duties.  ASEC  has  signed  a 
memorandum  of  understanding  (MOU)  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB),1 which 
provides for an overall framework of cooperation in support of RCI, and calls, in part, for ADB to 
enhance ASEC’s institutional capacity. This includes strengthening the Bureau of Economic 
Integration and Finance (BEIF). This technical assistance (TA) is designed to strengthen the 
capacity of ASEC—particularly BEIF—to support the ASEAN economic integration process, 
including implementation of the AEC. The design and monitoring framework is attached as 
Appendix 1.2  
II.   ISSUES 
 
4.  The AEC represents the economic integration espoused in ASEAN Vision 2020, which 
aims to deepen and broaden economic integration through existing and new initiatives with clear 
timelines. The AEC is expected to establish ASEAN as a single market and production base, 
thereby enhancing ASEAN’s economic competitiveness. New mechanisms and measures will 
be adopted to strengthen implementation of existing economic initiatives; to further accelerate 
ASEAN economic integration; to facilitate cross-border movement of business persons, skilled 
labor, and talent; and to strengthen the institutional mechanisms of ASEAN.  
 
5.  ASEC is mandated to “initiate, advise, coordinate and implement ASEAN activities.”3 
While ASEC is relatively effective to date, its administrative workload has increased with the 
recent rapid proliferation of ASEAN meetings and forums. With ASEAN as de facto hub for 
ASEAN+3 and East Asian cooperation generally, ASEC has taken on secretariat support for

bodies.  
2  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 13 July 2006. 
3  Fourth ASEAN Summit, Singapore, 1992.

2   
these  processes  as  well.  This  increased  administrative  burden  has  further  limited  ASEC’s 
capacity to fulfill its policy advisory role.4 
6.  Several international aid agencies have funded research programs to enable ASEC to 
address long-term policy issues on ASEAN economic integration: the United States Agency for 
International  Development  (USAID),  the  Australian  Agency  for  International  Development 
(AusAID), and the European Union (EU). Among others, their programs have supported the 
preparation  of  quality  research  papers  on  issues  related  to  ASEAN  economic  integration. 
However,  due  to  a  deepening  process  of  ASEAN  economic  integration,  ASEC  is  under 
increasing pressure to prepare timely policy notes and briefs at the request of relevant ASEAN 
bodies.  Thus,  to  make  support  more  demand-driven  to  ASEAN  and  more  responsive  to 
emerging issues, the TA’s approach is to integrate and mainstream such support within ASEC’s 
business process (see methodology and key activities).   
7.  Since the 1997/98 Asian financial crisis, ADB has supported ASEC through a number of 
TA  programs  for  the  ASP  and  ASEAN+3  ERPD. 5  Those  programs  have  significantly 
strengthened the capacity of ASEC and ASEAN member countries in regional economic and 
financial monitoring. As ASEAN economic cooperation in trade and investment has quickly 
gathered speed, it is also helpful to expand ADB’s support to these areas to further strengthen 
ASEC’s policy advisory role for ASEAN economic integration.  
8.  The demand for timely and quality policy briefs by ASEC is growing rapidly. Recently, 
AEM and AFM requested several policy briefs on emerging issues, such as a study of the 
impact  of  high  energy  prices  and  a  study  of  the  impact  of  the  proliferation  of  free  trade 
agreements (FTA). A deepening process of ASEAN economic integration will likely generate 
increased demands for quick policy responses. In the long term, ASEC needs to augment its 
“secretariat” function with a more research-oriented one. In the short term, ASEC requires 
increased capacity to respond to emerging policy issues of ASEAN economic integration. 
9.  ASEC is striving to enhance its capacity by realigning its organizational structure, e.g., 
merging the Bureau for Economic Integration (which dealt with trade and investment) and the 
Bureau for Finance and Integration Support (which dealt with macroeconomic surveillance and 
financial  integration)  into  the  new  BEIF.  Due  to  budgetary  constraints,  this  organizational 
realignment was a redeployment of staff rather than an increase in staff level. In the immediate 
and medium-term future, there is no plan to substantially increase the level of staff of ASEC, 
particularly BEIF, despite the growing number of ASEAN meetings. In the long term, the ASEAN 
Charter, which is being prepared by ASEAN member countries, is expected, among others, to 
identify innovative measures to increase the contributions of ASEAN member countries. This 
move may substantially provide greater opportunities for ASEC to augment its financial and 
human resources to sustain its functions. Thus, capacity support for ASEC in the short and 
medium term is needed. The TA will help provide additional capacity for ASEC in the form of 
consulting services.   
10.  ASEC  has  actually  requested  ADB  to  provide  research  and  support  for  capacity 
development since March 2006.6 A MOU between ASEC and ADB, which was initiated in 2005

staff are with BEIF. ASEC has to support around 500–600 ASEAN meetings annually. The bulk of ASEAN 
meetings is on economic issues, which are under the purview of BEIF.  
5  Regional TAs 5695, 6012, 5870, 5879, 6210, 6019, 5827, 6071, 6019, and 5827. 
6  The request was made at high-level consultations between ADB and the ASEAN Senior Economic Officials

3
and signed in August 2006, provides an overall framework of cooperation between the two in 
support of the ASEAN economic cooperation and integration process. ADB’s RCI strategy, 
adopted  in  July  2006,  outlines  ADB’s  broad  strategic  direction  in  supporting  economic 
cooperation and integration. The TA is consistent with RCI Pillar 2 (trade and investment 
cooperation and integration) and Pillar 3 (monetary and financial cooperation and integration). It 
will  help  ASEC  strengthen  its  capacity  to  support  ASEAN  economic  integration.  This  is 
particularly important as ASEAN strives to transform itself from a meetings-based association to 
a more rules-based institution—as outlined by ASEAN leaders at the 2007 Twelfth ASEAN 
Summit, Cebu, Philippines.   
III.   THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
11.  The TA aims to help improve the quality and effectiveness of ASEAN policy dialogue 
processes in the fora such as the AEM and AFM by strengthening the capacity of ASEC to 
respond to emerging issues of ASEAN economic integration, including implementation of the 
AEC. 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  The intended impact is improved quality and effectiveness of ASEAN policy dialogues 
for ASEAN economic integration. The expected outcome is an enhanced ASEC institutional 
capacity to (i) provide timely and quality policy briefs on selected topics that arise in the process 
of ASEAN economic integration, and (ii) monitor AEC implementation. 
 
13.  Expected results and deliverables include producing 
 
(i)  timely and effective research and policy briefings for AEM and AFM on issues 
related to ASEAN economic integration and policy dialogue (e.g., monetary and 
exchange  rate  policy,  development  of  regional  macroprudential  indicators, 
financial capital markets, trade and investment, among others); 
 
(ii)  capacity development programs for ASEC staff, including brief in-house training 
courses; and 
 
(iii)  a database on trade, investment, and services. Initial support will develop a 
database  structure  that  can  produce  enhanced,  predefined  tables  of  key 
macroeconomic and regional economic integration indicators. It will underpin an 
interactive statistical tool accessible from the ASEAN website. A later phase will 
develop a more sophisticated information management system to monitor AEC 
implementation.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.  The TA will consist of three major activities to support BEIF of ASEC: (i) research 
support, (ii) capacity development support, and (iii) database development. These activities will 
be  integrated  and  mainstreamed  within  the  BEIF  business  process.  Two  international 
consultants will be engaged and deployed to BEIF in Jakarta. One, a macroeconomist, will be 
assigned to the macroeconomic surveillance unit of BEIF. The other, a trade economist, will be 
assigned to the FTA Unit of BEIF. The two consultants will also serve as overall coordinators for 
ASEAN economic integration, including implementation of the AEC. The TA will also provide 
two national consultants to support the BEIF-based consultants.

4   
 
15.  The  TA  also  provides  a  separate  budget  allocation  to  engage  the  services  of 
international  consultants  in  relevant  fields  on  a  as  needed  basis  and  to  support  capacity 
development  activities.  The  budget  will  be  equally  allocated  between  the  macroeconomic 
surveillance and FTA units of BEIF, and will be managed by the Office of Regional Economic 
Integration (OREI). Disbursement to BEIF will be based on a work plan prepared every 6 
months and agreed upon in advance by OREI and BEIF. Among others, the work plan will 
identify clear outcomes and outputs, priority capacities, including both technical skills (e.g., 
macroeconomics/trade economics) and policy-oriented skills, and determine mechanisms for 
capacity development. Relevant ASEAN bodies such as the Senior Economic Officials Meeting 
(SEOM)  and  ASEAN  Deputy  Finance  Ministers  Meeting  (DFMM)  would  be  consulted  in 
preparing the work plan to ensure that emerging needs in 6 months would be reflected as much 
as possible. However, there will also be flexibility to address unforeseen issues that may arise 
during the implementation of the work plan. These unforeseen issues would have to be first 
agreed upon by relevant ASEAN bodies before being reflected in the work plan. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The total estimated cost of the TA is $720,000, of which $600,000 will be financed on a 
grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The cost will cover 
remuneration, travel, and per diem of consultants; research; database-building; publication and 
miscellaneous expenses.  ASEC will provide the balance of $120,000 (in kind) to cover office 
accommodation, administrative support, local staff salaries, and other overhead expenses. A 
detailed cost breakdown and proposed financing plan are in Appendix 2.   
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  The TA will be executed by ADB and managed by OREI, in close collaboration with the 
Southeast Asia Department (SERD). The regional TA is expected to start in May 2007 and be 
completed in April 2008, spanning 12 months.   
 
18.  Two BEIF-based consultants will be supervised by OREI and will report directly to OREI 
for major assignments. However, consultants’ day-to-day work will be administered by BEIF. 
The consultants’ reporting system will be specified by OREI and BEIF. All consultants will be 
engaged by ADB on an individual basis and in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2006, as amended from time to time).  
 
19.  The BEIF-based consultants are expected to (i) prepare (or assist in preparing) policy 
briefs  on  topics  identified  by  ASEC  and  agreed  to  by  ADB;  (ii)  assist  in  monitoring  and 
coordinating ASEAN economic cooperation and integration initiatives, including development of 
a  database  for  ASEC  to  monitor  ASEAN  economic  integration;  and  (iii)  provide  in-house 
capacity development  support. An outline of qualifications and terms of reference (TOR) of the 
consultants  are  in  Appendix  3.  Detailed  TOR  will  be  developed  when  the  TA  is  being 
implemented. 
 
20.  BEIF will (i) regularly apprise OREI on the research and training needs of its staff and 
(ii) recommend to OREI research topics and training activities to be undertaken. Consultation 
between BEIF and OREI will be held every 6 months to prepare work plans and to thoroughly 
monitor and evaluate the progress of the TA.

5
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening Capacity of the ASEAN Secretariat in Regional Economic Integration and Policy 
Dialogue, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

C.  National Consultants (24 person-months) 
 
3.  The  national  consultants  (research  assistant/economic  analysts)  should  have  a 
graduate-level background in macroeconomics or international trade with good knowledge of 
current developments in ASEAN economic integration. The research assistants will  
 
(i)  provide research assistance for the two BEIF-based consultants; 
(ii)  facilitate in-house seminars, workshops, and missions of OREI staff to ASEC; 
and  
(iii)  perform other functions as required. 
 
D.  International Consultants (as needed) 
4.  The  consultants  will  have  a  postgraduate-level  background  in  international  trade, 
macroeconomics, or public policy, with in-depth expertise in international trade policies, regional 
economic cooperation, trade negotiations; and substantial knowledge of current developments 
in ASEAN economic integration. The consultants will be engaged as needed and will report to 
ASEC through the ASEC-based consultants. The consultants will  
 
(i)  prepare studies and policy briefs as requested by ASEC,  
(ii)  develop the trade and investment database, 
(iii)  organize in-house training courses for ASEC staff, and 
(iv)  undertake other tasks as required by ASEC and OREI.
